Design Thinking and Data Science

So you want to get to know your audience

April 2, 2024

Every introduction to public speaking includes the admonititon to know your audience. I’ve had it on my own slides for years. But in my experience, it’s nice work if you can get it. Most of the time the actual composition of your audience is fuzzy at best and often a complete mystery so what is a desolate public speaker to do?

The Importance of Complaints

March 14, 2024

I am by my nature a complainer. I try to be pleasant, I try to be cheerful. No one wants to be the Negative Nelly.

Thinking Like A Statistician

March 7, 2024

Thought experiment: if you flip a coin 1000 times, what are the chances that you get 8 or more heads or tails in a row? If you said 1 in 256 (2 to the 8th), you’re wrong. If you didn’t say that, congratulations you’ve probably learned this material before and you can skip to the end.

The role of intuition in data science

March 7, 2024

I came upon a colleague at work. He was looking at a dataset that showed what he thought 1 was operator bias between two measurements. He was looking at the data as delta between the two measurements in a bar chart sorted by (a completely arbitrary) sample ID. The team was already half way through the tedious process of having new operators do new measurements to do a Gage R&R.

  1. My colleague of course thought nothing of the kind - his boss thought this and he had to run this analysis to cover his tail. ↩

Desire Paths and Data Product Failures

March 1, 2024

Desire paths are unplanned trails and an emergent property of many people making the same (predictable, understandable) choice to ignore the official path and taking a shorter one. It’s frequently a diagonal across a corner, or a path through a field when the landscaper would have walkers circumnavigate.

Design Thinking and Data Science

Email

LinkedIn

GitHub

Thinking about design thinking and how that interacts with data science. Can we use the principles of empathizing with our users, ideating, iterating and evaluating to make better, more elegant data products?
